19/ This is why pram tickets should never be reintroduced. For babies and their carers, the railway network should be fully accessible. Putting up any new barriers (physical, financial or attitudinal), however small, is unacceptable. We should be breaking barriers down. https://t.co/ddxJZDBmB2

18/ Indeed, there is a possibility that prams' exclusion from the free luggage allowance created a barrier to some carers - predominantly women in history - travelling by rail in later decades given the cost of the extra ticket.

(the rear of a c.1920 ticket shown) https://t.co/bcSWhknYAd

17/ This, then, is a good example of how attitudes towards mobility practices at one point in history, can structure the nature of mobility (or, potentially, the lack of it) in later decades, despite attitudes changing.

16/ The impact of this ruling was that prams were situated firmly outside of the category of 'ordinary luggage'. Indeed, despite attitudes evolving to consider them necessary for moving babies, until recently British railways continued to charge separately for them.

15/ ...fall foul of restrictions on weight or size of luggage,  it was not ordinary luggage defined as ‘articles as a traveller may usually carries, with him for his present convenience’. Rather, he claimed that ‘cases to take them [by train are]…the exception, and not the rule’

14/ Dissatisfied, Busfield went to court to claim back the 2s 6d, arguing again that where a baby was present, perambulators were ‘ordinary luggage.’ 

The judge, James John Lonsdale (shown) ruled that even though the perambulator did not...

Img source: https://t.co/WzzKUes1AV https://t.co/Dg95feoOmZ

13/ He argued that if one person claimed to carry a perambulator, another ‘might claim to carry a bath chair, and another by a very easy gradation might claim to have a small basket pony carriage conveyed as luggage’.

12/ ...and so felt the charge was illegal. 

Busfield raised the issue with the Midland’s General Manager, W.L. Newcombe. Newcombe didn’t see his point of view, viewing perambulators as being unnecessary for conveying infants.

11/ In 1858 J A Busfield and family were heading to the coast and back. On arrival at Bingley (shown), heading to Leeds, they were charged 2s 6d for a small perambulator. The family considered it ‘ordinary luggage' and it fitted within the size and weight limitations... https://t.co/HGamYc6YcF

10/ As they carried more of them in the 1850s, the railways began charging separately for perambulators. In line with prevailing views that they were unnecessary for baby movement, they were not considered 'ordinary' luggage.

This did not go unchallenged though.

9/ As per the railways’ authorising Acts of Parliament, passengers were allowed to carry with them free of charge a certain amount of ‘ordinary luggage’ (with weight and size limitations). But what constituted 'ordinary luggage' was open to interpretation, initially at least. https://t.co/ikDLtI37Aq

8/ Perambulators were therefore deemed by many to be unnecessary for baby transport. All they did was enhance carers' comfort. 

This perception of them being not a normal means of moving babies underpinned perambulator tickets' existence.
7/ He called on the Board of Health to clamp down on the ‘public nuisance’, and indeed Chavasse labelled them this too (img: Punch 3 May 1856) https://t.co/CDPXBpIloV

6/ Some also considered them an annoyance to other pedestrians. As a letter writer to the "Norwich Mercury" argued in 1859 that, where babies used to be carried, perambulators were now used ‘to the great annoyance and inconvenience to the public’. https://t.co/Y7sm1NKfWV

5/ Some believed that perambulators damaged children's health; later editions of Chavasse’s "Advice to a Mother on the Management of Her Children" (1839-1880s?) warned that they were ‘… very apt to make a child stoop, and to make him both crooked and round- shouldered.’ https://t.co/awSc3tR37o

4/ Consequently, there was a boom in perambulator manufacture, as a growing number of suppliers met demand. 

But not everyone was a fan, and resistance to their use came from various quarters.

3/ From the mid-1840s perambulator use expanded, especially amongst the wealthy. When in 1846 Queen Victoria purchased some, their popularity was given a boost.

https://t.co/gHSthtCdum

(Morning Advertiser - Friday 04 May 1855 - 1) https://t.co/8wsg9KaqmO

2/ Prams and buggies are now considered essential equipment for moving babies. This was however not so in the 19th c, the expectation being that they were carried by carers. Reflecting this, early railway timetables stated that free travel was given to babies/infants ‘in arms’. https://t.co/iWZxy0o4mZ

18/ Charles was connected by trade, family and partnership.

17/ But there is more beyond this to be understood. Charles's case shows that just because a railway investor did not receive compensation in the 1830s or own a plantation, does not mean their investment was not the result of the profits from enslavement.

16/ The Saunders family case is indicative of the nature of links between slavery and early railways. Looking for the connections does mean identifying plantation owners that reinvested their wealth into the railway and were involved in their building and management.

15/ James became secretary of the Eastern Union Rly in 1843. His obituary described how, like his brother, his exertions and existing business connections in London were critical in getting the line off the ground.

13/ Indeed, Channon suggested that his pre-existing experience and connections allowed him to move easily throughout political and commercial circles when seeking support (financial and otherwise) for the building of the GWR.

12/ His prior experience helped him in this role. In 1875 the Railway Times stated that his time as a merchant provided him with “an experience of life and aptitude in business matters which rendered him of the greatest use” in driving forwards the GWR project.
